material-property-value-condition.content: You are a knowledgeable assistant specialized in recognizing and understanding named entities and their interrelations. When requested to organize information in tabular format, you are adept at filtering and presenting only the relevant and valid results. You will exclude any results that are not pertinent or are inaccurate from the table according to the discussion history.

Please analyze the following paragraph and summarize the properties, including their numerical values, of the mentioned materials.

Paragraph: The decent hole mobilities of both copolymers can be attributed to high crystallinity of the copolymers due to the highly coplanar structure of anthracene and DPP . It is also understood that the 3 - fold higher chargecarrier mobility of PTATDPP than that of PTAFDPP arises from its stronger π - π stacking with a shorter d 010 , as discussed above . When the photovoltaic properties of copolymers are measured using PC71BM as an electron acceptor , it is found that the optimum blend ratio of polymer : PC71BM is 1 : 2 to afford the best PCE of both copolymers with the conventional device architecture of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / polymer : PC71BM / Ca / Al (Fig . S2 and Table S1 †) . The best PCE was also achieved when o - dichlorobenzene was used as a solvent and the optimum thickness for the active layer was ca . 90 nm . The current density - voltage (J - V) characteristics of the optimized solar cells are shown in Fig . 4 , and the relevant photovoltaic parameters of the devices are summarized in Tables 2 and S2 . † PTATDPP showed a best PCE of 6.69 % (V OC = 0.80 V , J SC = 12.3 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.68) , while PTAFDPP showed a best PCE of 5.02 % (V OC = 0.76 V , J SC = 11.2 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.59) . Both copolymers showed higher V OC s than other DPP - based copolymers due to their low - lying HOMO energy levels . Both copolymers also exhibited high J SC s and FFs , indicating their decent ability for charge generation and transport . Therefore , the TA unit is a promising electron - donating unit for low band - gap copolymers with a low - lying HOMO energy level . When the PSC devices were fabricated with an inverted architecture (ITO / ZnO / polymer : PC71BM / MoO 3 / Ag) in order to further improve the photovoltaic performance , the PCEs of PTATDPP and PTAFDPP - based devices were improved to 7.02 % and 5.22 % , respectively (Fig . 4b , Tables 2 and S2 †) , mainly due to enhanced J SC s (V OC s and FFs were not changed significantly) . It is noteworthy here that the PCE of over 7 % of PTATDPP is the highest efficiency of anthracene - based low band - gap conjugated copolymers . In spite of the same band - gap of the two copolymers , PTATDPP shows slightly higher J SC and FF than PTAFDPP (Fig . S3 †) . This can be ascribed to the closely packed microstructures of PTATDPP and thereby its high charge - carrier mobility than PTAFDPP . When the crystal structures of blend films of the copolymers with PC71BM were examined by XRD , the PTATDPP / PC71BM blend had strong and intense (100) diffraction while the PTAFDPP / PC71BM blend showed weak and broad (100) diffraction (Fig . 2b) .

Let's think step by step.

Step 1: Identify the mentioned materials and their properties.

Materials:
1. Copolymers (PTATDPP and PTAFDPP)
2. PC71BM (electron acceptor)
3. Solvent (o-dichlorobenzene)

Properties:
1. Hole mobilities
2. Crystallinity
3. Coplanar structure
4. π-π stacking
5. Charge-carrier mobility
6. Blend ratio of polymer: PC71BM
7. Photovoltaic properties
8. PCE (Power Conversion Efficiency)
9. Device architecture
10. Solvent used
11. Active layer thickness
12. Current density-voltage (J-V) characteristics
13. Photovoltaic parameters (VOC, JSC, FF)
14. HOMO energy levels
15. JSC (charge generation)
16. FF (charge transport)
17. TA unit (electron-donating unit)
18. Low band-gap copolymers
19. Inverted architecture
20. PCE improvement
21. Microstructures
22. Crystal structures
23. XRD (X-ray diffraction)

Step 2: Organize the properties and their numerical values in a table.

| Material   | Property                      | Numerical Value |
|------------|-------------------------------|-----------------|
| Copolymers | Hole mobilities               | Decent          |
| Copolymers | Crystallinity                 | High            |
| Copolymers | Coplanar structure            | Highly          |
| Copolymers | π-π stacking                  | Stronger        |
| Copolymers | Charge-carrier mobility       | 3-fold higher   |
| Copolymers | HOMO energy levels            | Low-lying       |
| Copolymers | JSC                           | High            |
| Copolymers | FF                            | High            |
| Copolymers | Microstructures               | Closely packed  |
| Copolymers | Crystal structures            | Strong and intense (PTATDPP/PC71BM), weak and broad (PTAFDPP/PC71BM) |
| PC71BM     | Electron acceptor             | -               |
| Solvent    | Used                          | o-dichlorobenzene |
| Active layer | Thickness                    | ca. 90 nm       |
| Device architecture | Used                  | ITO/PEDOT:PSS/polymer:PC71BM/Ca/Al (conventional), ITO/ZnO/polymer:PC71BM/MoO3/Ag (inverted) |
| Photovoltaic properties | Blend ratio       | 1:2 (polymer:PC71BM) |
| Photovoltaic properties | PCE               | PTATDPP: 6.69%, PTAFDPP: 5.02% (conventional), PTATDPP: 7.02%, PTAFDPP: 5.22% (inverted) |
| Photovoltaic parameters | VOC               | PTATDPP: 0.80 V, PTAFDPP: 0.76 V |
| Photovoltaic parameters | JSC               | PTATDPP: 12.3 mA cm^-2, PTAFDPP: 11.2 mA cm^-2 |
| Photovoltaic parameters | FF                | PTATDPP: 0.68, PTAFDPP: 0.59 |
| PCE        | Highest efficiency           | PTATDPP: over 7% |
| TA unit    | Electron-donating unit        | Promising       |
| Low band-gap copolymers | HOMO energy level | Low-lying       |

Note: Numerical values are provided where available.
